Continued discussion of “Enlightenment To Go – Shantideva and the Power of Compassion to Transform Your Life” by David Michie, 2010, Wisdom Publications

 

At the September and October 2011 meetings, the Manchester Buddhism Sangha discussed “The Way of the Boddhisattva” by Shantideva.  Shantideva was a scholar in the eighth century from the monastic university Nalanda, one of the most celebrated centers of learning in ancient India. Shantideva’s astounding teachings are certainly worth continued study. In “Enlightenment to Go” David Michie provides a lively, accessible introduction to the “best of” Shantideva’s writings. With warmth, humor, and stories of his own experiences, Michie shows how modern psychological science confirms Shantideva’s insights, as he explores their power to augment happiness and counter problems, such as stress, anxiety, and depression. Australian David Michie is the author of “Hurry Up and Meditate” and “Buddhism for Busy People.” 

 

A full reading of “The Way of the Boddhisattva” is highly recommended. An excellent translation is: "The Way of the Boddhisattva" by Shantideva, translated by the Padmakara Translation Group, published by Shambhala Library. This includes a foreword by the Dalai Lama, and helpful notes. The book is available in both hardcover and paperback. The teaching can also be found online in different translations.

 

For the February meeting, please read the first half of the book, and for the March meeting, please read the second half.
